title: This famous Boston brewery just opened its own restaurant - Food and dining
text:
MediaBoss Television of Framingham Framingham’s Jack’s Abby Brewing has a fresh new look, and with it, a restaurant that just opened this week, ahead of its scheduled grand opening on October 8.
The new beer hall and kitchen is located at 100 Clinton Street in Framingham. The restaurant will be open Tuesday through Friday and will serve dishes aimed to pair well with their beer offerings.
“[Jack’s Abby owners] tasked Chef Gregg Bergeron with creating a menu that would pair well with lots and lots of beer,” Jack’s Abby representative Sarah McGinley said. “What he created is a menu that features wood-fired pizza, inspired comfort-food options, and plates with a German flair. You can find a clam and bacon pizza, braised beef goulash cooked with our Smoke Dagger [Black Lager], four-cheese mac and cheese, and bratwurst with spaetzel all on the same menu.”
MediaBoss Television of Framingham The new space is about five times larger than Jack’s Abby’s previous digs, and focal points of the location include a copper-cased wood-fired pizza oven and a tapline that accommodates 24 unique brews.

New England pumpkin beers:

Photo courtesy of Long Trail Brewing Company Previous -- of -- Next Wolaver's: This Vermont brewery uses organic cinnamon, organic nutmeg, and organic cloves to create this golden amber ale—along with pumpkins from Golden Russet Farm in Shoreham, Vermont. Photo courtesy of Wolaver's Fine Organic Ales Previous -- of -- Next Cambridge Brewing Company: Back for its 26th run, Cambridge Brewing Company's Great Pumpkin Ale was the first New England craft beer to revive the pumpkin style from colonial days. Photo courtesy of Nina Gallant & Cambridge Brewing Company Previous -- of -- Next Magic Hat: This year, the Vermont company is releasing its first ever pumpkin ale, Wilhelm Scream (far left), named after the iconic scream sound effect that’s been used in over 200 movies. Photo courtesy of Magic Hat Brewing Company Previous -- of -- Next Samuel Adams: Pumpkin lovers rejoice—the Boston-based brewer will release three gourd-infused varieties for the fall season, including the Fat Jack (center), brewed with over 28 pounds of pumpkins per barrel. Photo courtesy of Boston Beer Company Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Harpoon: The Harpoon Brewery, based in Boston’s Seaport District, first added UFO Pumpkin to their line of unfiltered beers in 2011. Photo courtesy of Harpoon Brewery Previous -- of -- Next Two Roads: A slight twist on the typical pumpkin beer, Roadsmary's Baby by Two Roads is brewed in rum barrels. The result is a smooth ale with a touch of rum, pumpkin, vanilla, and oak. Photo courtesy of Two Roads Brewing Company Previous -- of -- Next Shipyard: Two pumpkin varieties will be available from this Portland, Maine, brewer this year. Pumpkinhead (right) is a crisp wheat ale with a subtle spicy flavor. Their signature series offering, Smashed Pumpkin (left), is a stronger beer (9 percent ABV) with pumpkin and nutmeg aromas. Photo courtesy of Shipyard Brewing Company Previous -- of -- Next Smuttynose: The top fall release from the New Hampshire brewer is their Pumpkin Ale, which they are now brewing for the twelfth year.
